data.title: Hannah Ableson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Hannah Ableson was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Sir Robert Adair (1583-1655)
data.bio: [Sir Robert Adair of Ballymenna and Kinhilt (1583-1655) was born in 1583 at Ballymena, co. Antrim, to Sir William and Rosina Adair. He was served heir to his father and grandfather in the Scottish estates on 19 February 1629. He was knighted by Charles I and became a Royalist soldier, before switching to the Scottish parliamentarians and became a major in the Earl of Leven's Horse Regiment. He commanded a regiment at the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644. Later, he commanded the cavalry at the 1650 Battle of Dunbar. He married Jane Edmonstone, and they had two sons and a daughter. He died on 1 March 1655 and was succeeded by his eldest son.]

data.title: Mr Ande (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Ande was a man living in the Ripon area in the late 1660s. He was married to Jane Wandesford, a cousin of Alice Thornton: possibly Jane Wandesford of Pickhill, daughter of Richard and Muriel Wandesford, born 4 March 1604. We have not been able to identify him further.]

data.title: Jane Ande (born 1604?)
data.bio: [Jane Ande née Wandesford married one Mr Ande by the late 1660s. She may be Jane Wandesford of Pickhill, daughter of Richard and Muriel Wandesford, baptised 4 March 1604 at Pickhill-cum-Roxby.]

data.title: George Anderson (n. d.)
data.bio: [George Anderson, a Scotsman, was a tutor to Thornton's brother, George Wandesford, in France. It is not known when George went to study under Anderson, but it was 'during the heat of the war', so he was probably there from 1642. George had returned to Yorkshire before the battle Marston Moor in July 1644. We have not been able to trace Anderson further.]

data.title: Sir Philip Anstruther (c.1630-1702)
data.bio: [This is probably Sir Philip Anstruther, the son of Sir Robert and Mary Anstruther born c. 1632. He inherited the Anstruther estate from his childless uncle John Anstruther in 1649. He was a Royalist colonel during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms and was captured at the final Royalist defeat at Worcester in 1651 and sequestered by Cromwell. He was reinstated under Charles II. He married Christian Lumsden and they had 7 sons and 3 daughters. He died in 1702.]

data.title: Charles Anthony (1600-1685)
data.bio: [Charles Anthony (1600-85) was born on 6 November 1600 and was educated at Jesus College, Cambridge (BA 1624, MA 1627). He was ordained in 1636 and became vicar of St Anne’s, Catterick in 1660. He baptised Alice Thornton's daughter, Elizabeth, in 1654. He died on 25 June 1685 and was buried at St Anne’s, Catterick.]

data.title: Katherine Armitage (1612-1667)
data.bio: [Katherine Armitage (1612-67) was baptised at St Peter's, Warmfield, on 27 February 1612, the oldest daughter and second child of Thomas and Elizabeth Danby of Farnley. She married Francis Armitage, later 1st Baronet, in 1629. They had at least 11 children, five of whom, three sons and two daughters, can be identified. A widow from 1644, she attended Katherine Danby, her sister-in-law, on her death bed in September 1645. She was buried on 13 January 1667 at Wakefield Cathedral.]

data.title: Allan Ascough (n. d.)
data.bio: [Allan Ascough was a kinsman of Alice Thornton's alive in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: John Ashton (1613-1642?)
data.bio: [Captain John Ashton (1613-42), baptised 19 September 1613 at the parish church of St John, Preston was the son of Radclyffe and Elizabeth Ashton of Cuerdale Hall. He married Anne Shuttleworth, and they had one son. He was Captain of the Foot during the first English Civil War which broke out in 1642. When Alice Thornton and her family fled Ireland in after the Irish Rebellion broke out in 1641, they were aided by Ashton on their journey through north-west England returning to Yorkshire. He died in October 1642 from wounds sustained at the Battle of Edge Hill.]

data.title: Dr. Atie (n. d.)
data.bio: [Dr Atie was a physician active in the Hambleton area in the late 1650s, perhaps an associate of Robert Wittie. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: William Ayscough (1648-1676)
data.bio: [William Ayscough of Osgoodby (1648-76) was born on 9 March 1648 to Sir William and Judith Ayscough. He (or perhaps his father) was one of the coffin bearers at William Thornton's funeral in September 1668, and he married Alice Thornton's sister-in-law, Anne Thornton, on 27 January 1676. He died within a year of marriage and was buried on 20 November 1676 at All Saints, Thirkleby.]

data.title: Anne Barrett (c.1626-1659)
data.bio: [Anne Barrett was the daughter of Robert and Eleanor Loftus, and the granddaughter of Adam Loftus, Lord Chancellor of Ireland, born c. 1626. She and her parents lived in the household of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, at Dublin in the late 1630s, when she kept company with a young Alice and Wentworth's daughters Anne and Arabella. She married Richard (Lennard) Barrett c.1653 and had four children, two sons and two daughters. She died on 4 April 1659.]

data.title: Sir Robert Barwick (c.1633-1666)
data.bio: [Sir Robert Barwick of Towlston was the son of Sir Robert Barwick, Recorder of York and Doncaster, and his second wife, Ursula, born c. 1633. He was admitted to Gray's Inn on 21 March 1641 and died on 16 June 1666.]

data.title: Dr John Bathurst (1597-1659)
data.bio: [John Bathurst (1597-1659) was baptised at St Dunstan’s church in Mayfield, East Sussex on 21 August 1597, the son of John and Dorothy Bathurst. John was a doctor in Goudhurst, Kent. He matriculated from Pembroke College Cambridge in 1614 and became a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in 1637. He was incorporated at Oxford in 1643 and acted as physician to Oliver Cromwell. He was MP for Richmond in 1656 and 1658. He married Elizabeth Willance on 27 January 1636, and they had 10 children, seven sons and three daughters. Alice Thornton's mother sent her son Christopher to Dr. Bathurst at York when he suffered a distemper from grief over his father's death in November 1643, and her brother John was likewise sent to him when he dropped out of Cambridge University and moved to London in a state of melancholy. He died on 19 April 1659.]

data.title: Mary Batt (born 1641)
data.bio: [Mary Batte was the daughter of John and Martha Batte, baptised at Birstall on 26 October 1641. In Book 3, she is identified as the person involved with Anne Danby in the plot to break up the marriage between Thomas Comber and Nally Thornton. However, in Book 1, Thornton identifies Mary's sister Martha. We have not been able to trace Mary further and this may be a misremembered name by Thornton. We do not know when she died.]

data.title: Martha Batte (1636-1667?)
data.bio: [Martha Batte, also known as Mattie, was the daughter of John and Martha Batte, baptised at Birstall, Yorkshire on 29 September 1636. She and her family emigrated to a plantation in Charles County, Virginia in 1649, where she was still living in 1665, when she and her brothers were granted a land patent for transporting slaves. By 1667 she was back in Yorkshire in the service of the Countess of Sussex at Howley Hall. She was a friend of Alice Thornton's niece-by-marriage, Anne Danby, from their time in Virginia. Elsewhere in her writing Thornton confuses Martha with Mary Batte, her sister. We do not know when she died.]

data.title: Mr Baxter (n. d.)
data.bio: Mr Baxter was a man acquainted with the Wandesford family who lived in Kent in the 1630s. We have not been able to trace him further.

data.title: [Unknown] Beal (n. d.)
data.bio: [Cousin Beal was a female relation of Alice Thornton's who bought some goods in London for Thornton's mother's house at Hipswell before 1659. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Thomas Belasyse (c.1627-1700)
data.bio: [Thomas Belasyse, 1st Earl Falconbridge was the son of Henry and Grace Belasyse, born at Newburgh Priory, near Coxwold, North Yorkshire in 1627/28. He married twice, first Mildred Saunderson in 1651, and then Mary, daughter of Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell, on 18 November 1657. He had no children. He inherited the title Viscount Falconbridge in 1653 and he took his seat as Lord Falconbridge in 1658. He became Lord Lieutenant of the North Riding and Durham in 1660. He died at Chiswick on 31 December 1700 and was buried at Coxwold on 31 January 1701.]

data.title: Gilbert Bennett (c.1599-1669)
data.bio: [Gilbert Bennet, born c. 1599, matriculated Christ's College Cambridge in July 1617 and graduated with his MA in 1624. He was ordained priest at Peterborough in 1625 and then held the prebendary of Southwell, Nottinghamshire from 1660. He was vicar of Carnaby 1662-4, rector of Stonegrave in 1663 and prebend of York 1667-9. He was buried at Southwell, Nottinghamshire on 10 December 1669.]

data.title: William Berridge (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Berridge was convicted of the murder of Thomas Danby, Alice Thornton's nephew, in a London tavern, in August 1667.]

data.title: Henry Best (died 1674)
data.bio: [Henry Best was the son of George and Grace Best of Middleton Quernhow. He married Katherine Danby, Alice Thornton’s niece, after 1659. After tricking his aunt, Alice Thornton, in 1666, he managed to become the beneficiary, along with three others, of a deed of William Thornton in relation to the settlement for Thornton’s daughters, Alice and Katherine. He had two children by Katherine, a son and a daughter. A barrister at Gray’s Inn, he died there in January 1674.]

data.title: Katherine Best (1637-1688)
data.bio: [Katherine Best (1637-88) was the daughter of Thomas and Katherine Danby; she was Alice Thornton's niece. She was born on 25 May 1637 at Richmond. She married Henry Best of Middleton Quernhow sometime after 1659 and they had two children, a son and a daughter. She was widowed in 1674 and died in 1688.]

data.title: Olive Best (1594-1654)
data.bio: This is likely Olive Best (1594-1654), the daughter of John and Anne Mallory. She became the second wife of Thomas Best on 17 January 1619, and was buried at St Mary’s, Wath on 16 June 1654.

data.title: Thomas Binks (n. d.)
data.bio: [Thomas Binks was a man in the Richmondshire area in the late 1640s or 1650s who warned Alice Thornton of Jeremy (later Jerome) Smithson's plan to abduct her. He was possibly a relation of the Smithson family, as Jane Smithson, Jerome's first cousin, married one Mr Binks, and a Cousin Francis Binks is mentioned in Jerome's brother Hugh's will in 1672. We do not know when he died.]

data.title: Thomas(?) Binlows (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Binlows was a minister active in the Richmondshire area in the late 1650s. He may be Thomas Binlows, preacher at Scruton, near Northallerton, from 1655. We do not know when he died.]

data.title: Katherine Blackburne (1645-1696?)
data.bio: [Katherine Blackburne, baptised 26 January 1645 at Grinton, was the daughter of Roger and Anne Covill of Fremington. She married Timothy Blackburne. She stood in for Thornton’s mother, who was unwell, at the baptism of Thornton's daughter, Elizabeth, in 1654. A widow from 1694, she was still alive in 1696 when she was named executrix in her mother's will.]

data.title: Sir John Borlase (c.1576-1648)
data.bio: [Sir John Borlase was born c.1576 in Cornwall to Edward and Suzannah Borlase. He attended Cambridge University, but did not graduate, and then pursued a military career. He fought extensively in the Low Countries in the early 17th century, becoming master-general of the ordnance of Ireland in 1634, and became Lord Justice of Ireland after the death of Alice Thornton's father Christopher Wandesford in 1640 along with Sir William Parsons. He married Alice (née Edwards), widow of Thomas Ravis, bishop of London, and they had three sons. He died at London on 15 March 1648 and was buried at Bartholomew-the-Great.]

data.title: Mr Bradley (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Bradley was a married acquaintance of William Thornton, who was in the Hambleton area of North Yorkshire in 1652. We have been unable to identify him more precisely.]

data.title: John Bramhall (1594-1663)
data.bio: [John Bramhall (1594-1663) was baptised at St Giles, Pontefract on 18 November 1594, one of six children of Peter Bramhall of Carleton. He graduated with a BA from Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1612, and was ordained in York in 1615. On 24 June 1618, Alice Thornton's father Christopher Wandesford presented him to the rectory of South Kilvington, near Thirsk. On 10 November 1618 he married a clergyman's widow, Ellen Collingwood. The couple had six children, three sons and three daughters. Wandesford and Thomas Wentworth helped Bramhall secure the prebend of Huisthwaite, Yorkshire in 1632. He became Bishop of Derry, in Ireland, in May 1634, and was present at Christopher Wandesford's deathbed in December 1640. He was one of the executors of Wandesford's will. After Wandesford's death he was exiled and had returned to his native Yorkshire by 1642; and was restored in Ireland by Charles II in 1660. He died on 25 June 1663.]

data.title: Robert Brandling (1617-1669)
data.bio: [This is probably Robert Brandling (1617-69), the son of Robert and Mary Brandling of Felling. He was a royalist Colonel of the Horse during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms.]

data.title: Sir William Brereton (1604-1661)
data.bio: [Sir William Brereton (1604–61), 1st Baronet, was born on 13 September 1604 to William and Margaret Brereton. A Puritan who owned extensive estates in Cheshire, and Member of Parliament for Cheshire at various times between 1628 and 1653, he was commander of Parliamentarian forces throughout the North Midlands during the First Civil War of 1642-47. He married twice; first, Susanna Booth in 1623, by whom he had four children, three daughters and a son; and, after her death, Cicely Mytton in 1641, a wealthy Staffordshire widow, by whom he had two more daughters. When the First Civil War ended, Brereton gave up his local offices and, although nominated as a judge, refused to attend the trial of Charles I in January 1649. He was elected to the Council of State in 1652 and 1653 but did not attend frequently, living in semi-retirement in London. He resumed his seat for Cheshire when the Long Parliament was reinstated in 1659, until its dissolution in March 1660, and died on 7 April 1661.]

data.title: Thomas Brockill (c.1617-1669)
data.bio: [Thomas Brockill was born c.1617 in Richmond, the son of John Brockill, a glover. He matriculated at St John's, Cambridge in 1635 and obtained his BA in 1639. He was master of Richmond school 1642-5 and vicar of St Mary’s, Hornby, from 1650-69. He married Susanna (surname unknown), and they had a son. He was rector of St Margaret’s, Tanfield from 1664 until his death and was buried there on 13 April 1669.]

data.title: James Brodricke (n. d.)
data.bio: [James Brodricke was footman for Alice Thornton's brother, George Wandesford, in the early 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Mrs Browne (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Browne was probably the wife of Thornton's possible cousin Benjamin Browne as they were present together at East Newton Hall in August 1662. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Benjamin Browne (1613-1681)
data.bio: [Benjamin Browne (1613-81) was the son of William Browne of Buckton, baptised at Bempton, East Riding on 28 June 1613. Thornton describes him as her 'cousin Browne' in one account, so it is possible that he was her kinsman, perhaps by marriage. He was educated at St John's Cambridge (BA 1639). He was instituted at St Mary's, Masham in 1639 and made vicar there in 1645. His role was sequestered in the 1650s, and he was restored there after the Restoration in 1661. He was probably married since he and a Mrs Browne both attended Thornton in August 1662 at East Newton when she took communion. He was ordained priest at York in September 1662. He was buried on 11 December 1681.]

data.title: Joseph Browning (n. d.)
data.bio: [Joseph Browning was a coachman active in Dublin in the mid-1630s, possibly an employee of the Wandesford family. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Mrs Bucke (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Bucke was possibly a servant in Alice Thornton's household or a local woman who was active in the Ryedale area in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: [Unknown] Bullock (n. d.)
data.bio: [Cousin Bullock, a male relation of Alice Thornton, was probably a descendant of Launcelot Bullock of Holme who married Margaret Thornton, the daughter of William Thornton's great-grandmother, making him a cousin-by-marriage to Alice Thornton. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: John Burniston (n. d.)
data.bio: [John Burniston was a witness of Christopher Wandesford's will in 1640. He is possibly the same John Burniston who was sword-bearer of Ireland under the Commonwealth in the 1650s.]

data.title: Dr Burton (n. d.)
data.bio: [Dr Burton was made a trustee of Alice Thornton's estate, from her parents, to ensure that it would go to her children. No further identification made.]

data.title: James Butler (1610-1688)
data.bio: [James Butler (1610-88) was born on 19 October 1610 to Thomas and Elizabeth Butler. He was an Anglo-Irish statesman and first Earl of Ormond. He married Elizabeth Preston at Christmas 1629, by whom he had 10 children, with three sons and two daughters surviving to adulthood. He was brought to Ireland by Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford, as head of government in Ireland in 1633. He commanded the Royalist forces in Ireland from 1641 and became Lord Lieutenant of Ireland on the Restoration of Charles II in 1660. He died at his estate of Kingston Lacey, Dorset, on 21 July 1688.]

data.title: [Unknown] Butterfeild – Butterfield? (n. d.)
data.bio: [Butterfeild was a tenant of Alice Thornton's on her mother's land, who Alice allowed to stay until the end of the lease after her mother's death.]

data.title: William Cavendish (1593-1676)
data.bio: [William Cavendish (1593-1676), 1st Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne, was baptised on 16 December 1593, the (second but first surviving) son of Charles Cavendish and his second wife, Catherine. He married twice, first Elizabeth Howard by whom he had five children (three sons and two daughters) and, second, Margaret Lucas. A writer, courtier and royalist army officer, he led his battalion, the Whitecoats, under the Royalist forces of Prince Rupert at the battle of Marston Moor in 1644. He died at Welbeck Abbey on Christmas Day 1676.]

data.title: Lady Katherine Cholmley (died 1657)
data.bio: [Katherine Cholmley (d.1657) was the daughter of Sir John Stanhope, 1st Lord Harrington, and his second wife, Margaret. She married Lord Robert Cholmley c.1610. She died on 15 June 1657 without issue and was buried in the chancel of St Oswald’s, Malpas.]

data.title: Ursula Cholmley (1600-1665?)
data.bio: [Ursula Cholmley was the eldest daughter of Robert Thornton and his first wife, Dorothy; she was William Thornton's half-sister. She was baptised on 13 March 1600 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. She married Marmaduke Cholmley of Bransby and they had a son and two daughters. She was still alive in November 1665 when William Thornton stopped at Bransby Hall during a journey.]

data.title: Sir Henry Cholmondeley (1609-1666)
data.bio: [Sir Henry Cholmondeley (1609-66) was the second surviving son of Sir Richard Cholmondeley and his wife, Susanna. He was originally intended for the legal profession but was expelled from the Temple after 1634 and married the wealthy widow of George Twiselton, Katherine, in the late 1630s. They had one daughter. He was MP for New Malton 1641-8. Cholmondeley was sent to Tangier in spring 1666 to oversee the harbour development but died there not long afterwards. His body was brought home and he was buried at West Newton Grange on 30 June 1666.]

data.title: Robert Cholmondeley (1584-1659)
data.bio: [Robert Cholmley (1584-1659), 1st Earl of Leinster, was born on 26 June 1584 in Middlesex to Sir Hugh and Mary Cholmley. He inherited the largest landed estate in Cheshire after his father's death in 1601. He was educated at Queen's College Oxford. He married Katherine Stanhope c.1610 and they had no children. He was MP for Cheshire in 1625 and a supporter of Charles I during the Civil War. He was made Earl of Leinster in 1646. He died on 2 October 1659 and was buried next to his late wife in the chancel of St Oswald’s, Malpas.]

data.title: William Clarkson (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Clarkson was ordained Minister of Kirklington in October 1644 after the death of Robert Daggett. He was also chaplain to Lord Ferdinando Fairfax (1584-1648) in the 1640s. According to Thornton, he was very unpopular at Kirklington church as he preached against the Lord's prayer. He was replaced by Michael Syddall in 1646.]

data.title: Sir John Clotworthy (died 1665)
data.bio: [John Clotworthy, 1st Viscount Massereene, was son of Sir Hugh and Mary Clotworthy of Antrim. He was knighted in 1626 and married Margaret Jones, daughter of Viscount Ranelagh. They had one daughter. He was an Anglo-Irish politician, a presbyterian and an opponent of Thomas Wentworth during his time as Lord Deputy of Ireland. He died in September 1665.]

data.title: Alice Comber (1654-1721)
data.bio: [Alice Comber (1654-1721), nicknamed Nally, was born on 3 January 1654 at Hipswell Hall to Alice and William Thornton and was baptised two days later. She was their second child and one of three Thornton children to survive to adulthood. She married Thomas Comber on 17 November 1668, by whom she had nine children (five sons and four daughters), with two sons and two daughters surviving childhood. She was Alice Thornton’s main heir in 1707 and inherited her books. She died on 20 January 1721 and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave two days later, where there is a memorial plaque.]

data.title: Dr Thomas Comber (1645-1699)
data.bio: [Thomas Comber (1645-99) was the son of James and Mary Comber of Westerham, Kent, born on 19 March 1645 and baptised on 23 March at the parish church. From a royalist family, he was educated at Westerham School before entering Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1659. He graduated with his BA in 1663 and became curate at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave at the behest of the absentee incumbent, Gilbert Bennett. He was ordained priest in September 1664 and in March 1665 he lodged with the Thorntons at East Newton for a year. After a further year of studies in Cambridge for an MA, he returned north. He married Thornton’s eldest daughter, Alice (Nally), in November 1668 and in 1669 he was made rector of Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. They had nine children, with two sons and two daughters surviving him. Comber wrote several treatises and books on religious topics. He became prebendary of York in 1677, precentor at York in 1683, and Dean of Durham in 1692. He was made chaplain-in-ordinary to the joint monarchs William and Mary in 1692. He died of consumption on 25 November 1699 at East Newton and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 30 November.]

data.title: Mary Cotes (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mary Cotes was probably a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Roger Covill (died 1664)
data.bio: [Roger Covill was the son and heir of John Covill, a gentleman of Lockthwaite, Westmoreland. He was admitted to the Inner Temple in September 1630, called to the bar in May 1639, and was then based at Fremington, Swaledale, He married Anne Norton, a relation of Alice Thornton’s, at Scruton on 17 June 1641. The couple had two daughters. He drafted a deed at Alice Thornton’s request in 1662. He was buried on 12 July 1664 at St Andrew’s, Grinton; his will was proved in 1665.]

data.title: John Crathorne (born c.1642)
data.bio: [John Crathorne was born c.1642, the son of Ralph Crathorne and his second wife, Margaret. He was William Thornton's nephew.]

data.title: Margaret Crathorne (born 1608)
data.bio: [Margaret Crathorne was the daughter of Robert Thornton and his first wife Dorothy, baptised 9 May 1608 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. She was William Thornton's half-sister. Around 1632 she became the second wife of Ralph Crathorne of Crathorne, and they had a daughter and three sons. We do not know when she died.]

data.title: Ralph Crathorne (1604-1665?)
data.bio: [Ralph Crathorne was the first son and heir of Thomas and Catherine Crathorne, born in 1604. He married twice; first, Mary Wright, by whom he had a son and a daughter, and second, Margaret Thornton, sister of William Thornton; Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. With Margaret he had four children, three sons and a daughter. He was still alive in 1665.]

data.title: Ralph Crathorne (c.1634-1668?)
data.bio: [Ralph Crathorne was born c.1634, the first son of Ralph Crathorne of Crathorne and his second wife, Margaret. He was William Thornton's nephew. He married Anne Tunstall, and they had three sons. We do not know when he died.]

data.title: Oliver Cromwell (1599-1658)
data.bio: [Oliver Cromwell (1599-1658), was Lord Protector of England, Wales and Ireland during the Interregnum period of 1649 until his death in 1658. Born 25 April 1599, the son of Robert and Elizabeth Cromwell, he was educated at Sidney Sussex College Cambridge and married Elizabeth Bourchier in 1621. They had nine children - five sons and four daughters. He died on 3 September 1658.]

data.title: Richard Cromwell (1626-1712)
data.bio: [Richard Cromwell (1626-1712), born 4 October 1626, was the third son, and fourth child, of Oliver and Elizabeth Cromwell. On his father's death in September 1658, he was elected Lord Protector of England, a position he held until 1659, when the Protectorate collapsed. He married Dorothy Maijor on 1 May 1649, and they had nine children, only four of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 12 July 1712.]

data.title: Mr Culliss (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Culliss was a man to whom Gilbert Bennett, rector of Stonegrave from 1663, wished to marry one of his daughters. We have not been able to identify him further.]

data.title: Robert Daggett (c.1587-1644)
data.bio: [Robert Daggett of Howe was born c.1587. He studied at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, matriculated in 1605 and received his MA in 1612. He was ordained priest in 1613 and incorporated at Oxford in 1614. He was awarded his Bachelor of Divinity in 1619. He became Rector of Kirklington in April 1639. The Thornton family stayed with him in Kirklington in 1643-4 while waiting for Hipswell Hall to be ready for habitation. He died on 19 August 1644 and was buried at St Michael, Kirklington.]

data.title: Lady Elizabeth Dalton (1631-1711)
data.bio: [This is probably Elizabeth Dalton daughter of Marmaduke Wyvill, 2nd Baronet of Constable Burton, and his wife, Isabel. Elizabeth married Sir William, Dalton of Hauxwell Hall. They had 10 children, six sons and four daughters.]

data.title: Mr Danby (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Danby bought a rent charge from William Thornton to pay debts in the late 1650s or 1660s. It has not been possible to identify him further.]

data.title: Sir Abstrupus Danby (1655-1727)
data.bio: [Sir Abstrupus Danby (1655-1727) was the first son of Christopher and Anne Danby, born 27 December 1655. He was Alice Thornton's great-nephew. Before 1679 he married Judith Moone and they had a son. Abstrupus inherited an estate that was in debt and so sold off much of the family's property but came to be known as the 'Restorer' of his family. He was knighted in 1691 and became was MP for Aldborough 1698-1700. Defeated when he recontested his seat in 1701, he retained an active interest in Yorkshire politics until his death on 27 December 1727.]

data.title: Alice Danby (born 1641)
data.bio: [Alice Danby was born 22 May 1641 in Greenwich and baptised on 5 June at St Alfege's, Greenwich. She was the daughter of Thomas and Katherine Danby, making her Alice Thornton's niece. She was still alive – and unmarried - in 1675, when she was involved in a lawsuit with some of her siblings against her elder brother's widow, Margaret Danby.]

data.title: Anne Danby (1630-1695)
data.bio: [Anne Danby (1630-1695) was the daughter of Mr John Culpeper, who, according to her son Abstrupus, was the younger brother of Sir John Culpeper. Anne says that he was a royalist in England who had to flee to Virginia due to his support for the king, meaning Anne was born in England. Anne also mentions being related to Lady Berkeley (Frances Culpeper Berkeley), wife to three colonial governors of Virginia. While in Virginia, c.1652, Anne married Christopher Danby, son of Katherine and Thomas Danby, becoming Alice Thornton's niece. Christopher's father did not approve of the match. Her first child born in Virginia in 1653 died straight after the birth. The couple relocated to Yorkshire and lived with Christopher's older brother, Thomas Danby, at Farnley Hall and had five more children, three sons and two daughters. It seems that Anne and her family lived with the Thorntons at East Newton at least twice in the 1660s: firstly in 1661 or 1662 for three months and later, after the death of Thomas Danby, in 1667, when she was cast out by Thomas’s widow, Margaret. In 1668, she was allegedly the source of rumours about Thomas Comber and the Thornton women, resulting in her being evicted from the Thornton household by William. She died on 11 November 1695 and was buried at Holy Trinity Church, Micklegate, York.]

data.title: Charles Danby (1643-1672)
data.bio: [Charles Danby (1643-72) was the son of Thomas and Katherine Danby, born on 2 June 1643 at Snape; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. He matriculated at Gonville and Caius, Cambridge, in 1661 and was admitted to Gray's Inn in January 1664. He died without issue in April 1672.]

data.title: Christopher Danby (1632-1689)
data.bio: [Christopher Danby (1632-89) was the second son of Thomas and Katherine Danby, born 30 July 1632 at St-Martin-in-the-Fields, London; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. After his mother's death in 1645, the family emigrated to Virginia in 1650 and around 1652 he married Anne Culpeper, against his father's wishes. Their first child, born in Virginia, died straight after birth. They moved back to Yorkshire and had five children, three sons and two daughters. On his older brother’s death in 1667, he became heir to his father's estate, but granted this estate to his son Abstrupus in the same year, as he was thought incapable of running it. He was buried on 25 November 1689 at St Mary’s, Masham.]

data.title: Edward Danby (n. d.)
data.bio: [Edward Danby (1644-47) was the ninth child of Sir Thomas Danby and his wife, Katherine. He was born on 26 August 1644 when his parents were hiding at Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, and named after a sibling who had died as a baby in 1634. Alice Thornton, his aunt and godmother, was present for his birth and/or baptism. He died on 6 July 1647 and was buried at Leeds.]

data.title: Francis Danby (1640-1645)
data.bio: [Francis Danby (1640-45) was born on 22 March 1640 at Farnley, the son of Thomas and Katherine Danby; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. He died in July 1645 and was buried at St Michael the Archangel, Well, Bedale. Thomas and Katherine's youngest son, born August 1645, was named after him.]

data.title: Francis Danby (1645-1672?)
data.bio: [Francis Danby was the youngest son of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford, born at Thorpe Perrow on 27 August 1645. He was Alice Thornton's nephew, named after his brother who had died the month before. His mother died shortly after his birth from postpartum complications. He and his brother John were involved in a protracted legal suit with his sister-in-law Margaret Danby, widow of his eldest brother Thomas, throughout the 1670s. He was still alive in November 1680 when the rehearing of the case was ongoing.]

data.title: Katherine Danby (1615-1645)
data.bio: [Katherine Danby (1615-45) was the eldest child of Christopher and Alice Wandesford; older sister of Alice Thornton. She was baptised on 20 October 1615 at St Michael the Archangel, Kirklington. She married Thomas Danby in July 1630, aged 14. She was pregnant 16 times but suffered six stillbirths. Of the couple's 10 baptised children, eight were boys and two were girls; seven of her 10 children survived infancy. She died on 10 September 1645, aged 29, at Thorpe Perrow of postpartum complications. She was buried at St Mary’s, Masham the next day.]

data.title: Margaret Danby (c.1640-1688)
data.bio: [Margaret Danby (c.1640-88) was the daughter of William and Margaret Eure of Ingleby. She married Thomas Danby, son and heir of Thomas and Katherine Danby of Thorpe Perrow, in 1659; this made her Alice Thornton's niece by marriage. They had three children, a son and two daughters. She was widowed by the murder of her husband near Gray's Inn in August 1667, later rumoured to perhaps be at her instigation. She spent much of her widowhood in conflict with other members of the Danby family over her husband's estate. She died on 23 June 1688.]

data.title: Sir Thomas Danby (1610-1660)
data.bio: [Sir Thomas Danby (1610-60) was the son of Christopher and Frances Danby of Farnley, baptised 8 August 1610 at St Mary’s, Masham. A ward of Christopher Wandesford after his father's death in 1624 and a protracted legal dispute, he entered St John's College, Cambridge in 1627. He married Christopher Wandesford’s daughter, Katherine, in 1630, making him Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. He was knighted in 1633, became Sheriff of York in 1637 and was elected MP for Richmond in 1640. He was banned from sitting in Parliament after 1642 and was fined heavily for his loyalty to Charles I. He and Katherine had 10 live-born children, seven of whom survived to adulthood. After his wife's death in 1645, he relocated to Virginia where he held lands, moving back to Yorkshire in the 1650s. He died in London on 5 August 1660 and was buried in the north aisle of the choir at York Minster. In his will, he left tobacco plantations in Virginia to his son Christopher and wife, Anne.]

data.title: Thomas Danby (c.1617-1645)
data.bio: [This is possibly Thomas Danby, second son of Thomas and Elizabeth Danby of Braworth, born c. 1617, and possibly the same man involved in a court of chivalry case in 1638 against John Bates of York, whom he claimed had verbally abused him and denied his gentility. He fought for the Royalists in the 1640s and was killed at the Battle of Naseby on 14 June 1645.]

data.title: Thomas Danby (1631-1667)
data.bio: [Thomas Danby (1631-67) was born on 17 August 1631 in Westminster, the oldest son and heir of Sir Thomas and Katherine Danby; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. He married Margaret Eure in 1658 and they had three children, a son and two daughters. In 1661 he became the first Mayor of Leeds. He was also briefly MP for Malton in 1661. He was killed in a tavern near Gray's Inn, London, on 31 July 1667. William Berridge, Thomas Jenney and John Ogle were accused of his murder but there were later rumours that his wife was involved in his death.]

data.title: Conyers Darcy (1599-1689)
data.bio: [Sir Conyers Darcy, 1st Earl of Holdernesse, 8th Lord Darcy de Knayth (1599-1689) was born on 24 January 1599 to Sir Conyers and Dorothy Darcy. He was constable of Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, and created Earl of Holderness on 6 December 1682. On 14 October 1616 he married Grace, the only daughter and heir of Thomas Rokeby, of Skyers. They had six sons and five daughters, only one of the sons, Conyers, surviving childhood. He died on 14 June 1689 in Hornby, Yorkshire.]

data.title: Conyers Darcy (1622-1692)
data.bio: [Conyers Darcy (1622-92), 2nd Earl Holdernesse, baptised 3 March 1622 at St Michael le Belfrey, York, was the son and heir of Conyers and Grace Darcy. Educated at University College, Oxford (1637), he entered Gray's Inn in 1640. He married four times: to Catherine Fane, Frances Howard, Frances Seymour and Elizabeth Frescheville. With Frances Howard he had six children, three sons and three daughters. He was elected MP for Boroughbridge in 1660, and became a peer in 1680, as Baron Conyers. He died at Aston on 13 December 1692.]

data.title: Dorothy Darcy (1572-1653)
data.bio: [Dorothy Darcy (1572-1653) was the daughter of Henry and Ursula Belasyse. She married Conyers Darcy, 4th Lord Conyers, on 2 May 1594 at Coxwold, with whom she had 12 children, six sons and six daughters. She died on 11 May 1653 in Hornby.]

data.title: Lady Frances Darcy (1623-1670)
data.bio: [Lady Frances Darcy (1623-1670) was the daughter of Thomas Howard, 1st Earl of Berkshire and his wife Elizabeth, baptised 19 October 1623 at St Martin-in-the-Fields, London. On 6 February 1650 she became the second wife of Lord Conyers Darcy, 2nd Earl Holdernesse. They had six children, three sons and three daughters. She was buried at Hornby on 10 April 1670.]

data.title: Henry Darcy (1610-1662)
data.bio: [Henry Darcy (1610-62) was the third son of Conyers and Dorothy Darcy, baptised 19 October 1610 at Hornby. He married Mary Scrope in 1628 and they had 10 children. He died on 28 April 1662 and was buried at St Olave's, York.]

data.title: Isabel Darcy (died 1660)
data.bio: [Isabel Darcy was the daughter of Marmaduke Wyvill, second baronet of Burton Constable and his wife, Isabel. Before 1650 she married James Darcy of Sedbury Park, and they had three sons and four daughters. She died in 1660.]

data.title: James Darcy (1617-c.1673)
data.bio: [James Darcy was the sixth son of Conyers and Dorothy Darcy, born August 1617. He married Isabel Wyvill, and they had seven children, three sons and four daughters. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1660 but was not re-elected in 1661, being then appointed to Master of the Royal Stud. He died after 13 October 1673, when his will is dated.]

data.title: Elizabeth Darley (n. d.)
data.bio: [Elizabeth Darley was the daughter of Sir William and Isabel Hildyard of Bishop Wilton. She married Richard Darley, the brother of William Thornton's mother, on 20 December 1632 at Bishop Wilton, making her Alice Thornton's aunt-by-marriage. She was also the niece of Catherine Hansby, Alice Thornton's great-grandmother, via her mother Isabel. Richard and Elizabeth had five children, four sons and a daughter. She was buried at Bishop Wilton.]

data.title: Francis Darley (1605-1679)
data.bio: [Francis Darley (1605-79) was the son Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire and his second wife, Elizabeth, born 1605; he was William Thornton's uncle via his sister Elizabeth. He was one of the executors of Alice Wandesford’s will in 1659. He is possibly the Francis Darley of Awdby given land in 1665, mentioned in William Thornton’s settlement of his daughters made 19 September 1667. He was buried at Buttercrambe on 31 December 1679.]

data.title: John Darley (n. d.)
data.bio: [John Darley held a bond with William Thornton for £1000 for the performance of covenants to Sir Henry Cholmondeley dated 7 August 1662. We have not been able to identify him with any certainty, but he was possibly related to William Thornton via William's mother, who was born Elizabeth Darley.]

data.title: Richard Darley (c.1602-1681)
data.bio: [Richard Darley was the third son of Sir Richard and Elizabeth Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire, born c. 1602. He was William Thornton's uncle, a younger brother of his mother Elizabeth. He married Elizabeth Hildyard, the niece of Catherine Hansby (Alice Thornton's great-grandmother), on 20 December 1632 at Bishop-Wilton, York. Elizabeth and Richard had six children, five sons and a daughter. He sat on the committee at York that dealt with sequestration, and via a deal with Thornton's uncle, William Wandesford, he was able to regain the family estate at Kirklington for her brother George Wandesford. After Wandesford’s death Alice married his nephew William Thornton. He died on 2 February 1681 and was buried at Bishop Wilton.]

data.title: Elizabeth Denton (1622-1669)
data.bio: [Elizabeth Denton (1622-1669) was the first child of Robert Thornton and his second wife Elizabeth, baptised 24 September 1622 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave; she was Alice Thornton's sister-in-law. She married John Denton, minister of Oswaldkirk, on 8 May 1654 at East Newton. They had at least two sons. She was buried on 14 February 1669.]

data.title: John Denton (1625-1709)
data.bio: [John Denton (1625-1709) was baptised on 2 February 1625 at St Andrew’s Church, Kildwick-in-Craven, the son of John and Elizabeth Denton of Steeton. He studied at Clare College Cambridge, gaining his MA in 1653. He became minister of Oswaldkirk in 1654. In the same year, he married Elizabeth Thornton, older sister of William Thornton. He was ejected from Oswaldkirk in 1662 for nonconformity, after which he served as curate at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave, under Thomas Comber. Elizabeth died in 1669 and Denton remarried. His second wife, also named Elizabeth, died in 1715. With his first wife he had one or two sons, and with his second wife he had two sons and two daughters. He died on 14 January 1709 and was buried on 16 January in the north aisle of Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.]

data.title: John Denton (born 1655)
data.bio: [John Denton was the son of John and Elizabeth Denton, baptised on 5 September 1655 at Oswaldkirk; he was William Thornton's nephew. He attended Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, where he received his BA in 1677. We do not know when he died.]

data.title: Robert Denton (c.1615-1665?)
data.bio: [Robert Denton of Nawton was the son of Thomas and Barbara Denton, born c. 1615. He married Anne Maw in 1640 at Kirkdale and they had two sons and two daughters. He was still alive in 1665.]

data.title: William Denton (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Denton was probably the son of John and Elizabeth Denton; he was Alice and William Thornton's nephew. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Sir James Dillon (c.1600-1669?)
data.bio: [Sir James Dillon was the youngest son of Theobald and Eleanor Dillon, born c. 1600. An army officer, he became Commissioner of Ireland in 1627. He was elected MP for Co. Westmeath in 1634. Commissioned by Charles I in 1640 to recruit regiments from disbanded soldiers in Ireland, he was said to have been involved in the 1641 plot to seize Dublin castle. He married twice, first Elizabeth Plunkett in the 1630s, with whom he had two sons. Elizabeth died before 1653. His second marriage, in the early 1660s, was to Mary Ridge, a widow. He was still alive in 1669.]

data.title: John Dodsworth (1597-1670)
data.bio: [John Dodsworth of Thornton Watlass (1597-1670) was the son of John and Winifred Dodsworth, baptised on 21 September 1597 at St Gregory’s, Bedale. He matriculated Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge on 23 January 1613 and was admitted to Gray’s Inn on 24 March 1624. He married Frances Hutton, and they had five children, three sons and two daughters. He was buried at St Mary’s, Thornton Watlass on 20 June 1670.]

data.title: Timothy Dodsworth (1622-1673?)
data.bio: [Timothy Dodsworth was the son of John and Frances Dodsworth of Thornton Watlass, baptised on 1 January 1622 at Thornton Watlass. He was Christopher Wandesford's servant in Ireland when he was Master of Rolls in the 1630s, and then entered Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1637. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in January 1640. He married Dorothy Stringer on 14 April 1646 at St Bartholomew the Less, London, and they had a son and a daughter. He died before 1673.]

data.title: Christopher(?) Driffield (n. d.)
data.bio: [This is probably Christopher Driffield of Easingwold, admitted to Gray's Inn in December 1650 and made Recorder of Ripon in 1673. He had at least one son, Christopher.]

data.title: Toby Dudley (c.1597-1661)
data.bio: [Toby Dudley, born c. 1597, was the oldest son and heir of Ambrose Dudley of Chopwell, Northumberland. He married Jane Blackiston, and they had one child, Jane. He was buried at Holy Cross, Ryton in 1661.]

data.title: Thomas(?) Edmunds (c.1596-1662)
data.bio: [This is probably Thomas Edmunds of Worsborough, Yorkshire, born c. 1596, secretary to the Earl of Strafford. He died on 9 January 1662.]

data.title: Mr Edrington (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Edrington was a clergyman active in North Yorkshire in the late 1650s. He may be the vicar of Langton who graduated from St John's Cambridge in 1644; or a William Etherington who was instituted at St Agatha's, Gilling, in 1665.]

data.search: Church of St Oswald, Oswaldkirk, Yorkshire _place_Oswa_130
data.title: Church of St Oswald, Oswaldkirk, Yorkshire
[Unknown] Fairfax (n. d.)
data.bio: [Cousin Fairfax was a female relation of Alice Thornton, possibly a descendant of Guy Fairfax of Gilling and Anne Thornton of East Newton who married in the mid-16th century. Anne Thornton was Alice's husband William's great-great-great-aunt. We have not been able to trace her any further.]

data.title: [Unknown] Fairfax (n. d.)
data.bio: [Niece Fairfax was a female relation of Alice Thornton, probably a descendant of Guy Fairfax of Gilling and Anne Thornton of East Newton who married in the mid-16th century. Anne Thornton was Alice's husband William's great-great-great-aunt. We have not been able to trace her any further.]

data.title: Lady Anne Fairfax (c.1617-1665)
data.bio: [This is probably Anne Fairfax, the daughter of Horace de Vere, Lord Tilbury and his wife Mary, born in 1617/18. She married Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord of Cameron on 20 June 1637 and they had two daughters. She and her husband retired to their estate at Nun Appleton, Yorkshire during the Interregnum. She died on 16 October 1666.]

data.title: Thomas Fairfax (1612-1671)
data.bio: [Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord of Cameron (1612-71) was the son of Ferdinando Fairfax, 2nd Lord Cameron of Denton, Yorkshire and his first wife Mary, born 17 January 1612. He was educated at St John's College, Cambridge, matriculating in 1626 and entered Gray's Inn in 1628. He was commander-in-chief of the Parliamentarian forces during the First Civil War and leader of the New Model Army from 1645, but refused to participate in the trial and execution of Charles I. He married Anne, and they had two daughters, Mary and Anne (who died as a toddler). He and his wife retired to Nun Appleton, Yorkshire, after the King's execution and he died on 12 November 1671 after having been instrumental in the Restoration of Charles II.]

data.title: George Farrer (born 1610?)
data.bio: [George Farrer was perhaps baptised on 28 October 1610 at Coxwold, the son of Nathaniel Farrer of Closehouse. He was probably the minister of Thornton Watlass, made rector of St Mary the Virgin in 1635. He may have studied at Alban Hall, Oxford in 1625 or he may have studied at Cambridge. Jackson suggests he may have been a chaplain at the Malton household of the Eure family. He was the recipient of a letter of Anne Danby shortly after her eviction from the Thornton household in 1668, and seems to have been acting as a mediator between Danby and her sister-in-law, Margaret. We do not know when he died.]

data.title: Katherine Farrer (n. d.)
data.bio: [Katherine Farrer was a friend of Anne Danby, whom Anne tried to set up with Thomas Comber. Anne Danby's letter to Parson Farrer, mentioned in Alice's books, indicates that Katherine was a relation of his. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Charles Feild (n. d.)
data.bio: [Charles Feild was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the late 1660s. We have not been able to identify him further.]

data.title: Normavill Fisher (n. d.)
data.bio: [Normavill Fisher was a young man of 18 in the service of Anne Norton, Alice Thornton's aunt, at St Nicholas, Richmond. He was perhaps born out of wedlock and also perhaps fathered a child. We have not been able to identify him further.]

data.title: Thomas Flathers (c.1616-1686)
data.bio: [Thomas Flathers was the son of Marmaduke Flathers of Weston (later rector of Hemsworth) and his wife, a daughter of John Proctor of New Hall, near Otley. Born c. 1616, he was educated at Wakefield and Coxwold schools, and then Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, graduating with a BA in 1635/6. He was ordained deacon in 1638 and priest in 1639. He was vicar of North Grimston 1640-62, and vicar of Lastingham and Rural Dean of Ryedale from September 1662. He died in 1686.]

data.title: Charles Fleetwood (c.1618-1692)
data.bio: [Charles Fleetwood was the third son of Sir Miles and Anne Fleetwood of Aldwincle, Northamptonshire born c. 1618 (mistaken here for his father by Alice Thornton). Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge, he entered Gray's Inn on 30 November 1638. A parliamentarian soldier during the 1640s, leading troops at the Battle of Naseby, he rose to prominence during the Interregnum and became Commander in Chief of the parliamentary forces in Ireland in 1652, and Lord Deputy in 1654. He married three times, firstly Frances Smith, then Bridget, daughter of Oliver Cromwell and widow of Henry Ireton, previous Commander of Ireland. Bridget died in 1662 and in 1664 he married Mary, daughter of Sir John Coke. With Frances he had two children, Frances and Smith, and with Bridget three, two of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 4 October 1692 and was buried at Bunhill Fields, London.]

data.title: Edward Fleetwood (c.1534-1604)
data.bio: [Edward Fleetwood was the son of Thomas Fleetwood and his second wife, Bridget, born c. 1534. He was the brother of Alice Thornton's maternal grandmother, Joyce Osborne. He studied at St Alban Hall, Oxford (MA 1575), and married Christian Wentworth. The couple had at least four children. He was instituted rector of Wigan in 1571, a position he held until his death on 12 October 1604.]

data.title: Sir Miles Fleetwood (1576-1641)
data.bio: [Sir Miles Fleetwood of Aldwinkle (1576-1641) was baptised on 1 October 1576. Thornton confuses him here with her maternal great-grandfather, Thomas Fleetwood, although he was related to her via her maternal grandmother Joyce - her brother William Fleetwood was Miles’s father. He married Anne Luke and they had four sons and four daughters. He was MP in several constituencies across England in the 1620s and 1630s, and was elected MP for Hindon, Wiltshire, in the Short Parliament of 1640, which he held until his death on 8 March 1641.]

data.title: Jane Flouer (n. d.)
data.bio: [Jane Flouer was a servant in Alice Wandesford’s household at Hipswell in the 1650s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: James Foxcraft (n. d.)
data.bio: [James Foxcraft was a friend or acquaintance of Christopher Wandesford living in Dublin in the early 1640s. He may have come to Ireland with Wandesford as one of his men, in which case, he was possibly the James Foxcraft of Bargrange born in 1594 at Leeds. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: William Foxley (c.1609-1680)
data.bio: [William Foxley, born c. 1609, was Mayor of Hull in 1657 and 1676. He died on 24 September 1680. He is misnamed here by Thornton.]

data.title: Lady Arabella Frankland (c.1638-1687)
data.bio: [This is probably Lady Arabella Frankland, born c. 1638, daughter of Henry and Grace Belasyse. In 1662 she married Sir William Frankland of Thirkleby and they had nine children, four sons and a daughter surviving childhood. She died on 26 February 1687 and was buried at All Saints, Thirkleby.]

data.title: Sir John Frescheville (1606-1682)
data.bio: [John Frescheville (1606-82), first Baron Frescheville, was the son of Sir Peter Frescheville and his first wife, Joyce, born 1606. He was Alice Thornton's uncle, the younger half-brother of her mother, Alice Wandesford. He was educated at Magdalen Hall Oxford and the Middle Temple (1624). He married twice; firstly Bruce Nicholls, who died in 1629 without issue, and then Sarah Harington with whom he had three daughters. He was elected MP for Derbyshire in 1628, the year before the abolition of Parliament by Charles I. He was Lieutenant of Derbyshire from 1630-42, and then became a Captain in the Royalist army. He was executor of Alice Wandesford’s will in 1659 and named trustee for Alice and William Thornton's daughters in their settlement of 1667. He was created Baron in 1665 and died without a male heir to inherit his baronetcy on 31 March 1682.]

data.title: Sir Peter Frescheville (1575-1634)
data.bio: [Sir Peter Frescheville (1575-1634) was the eldest son of Peter Frescheville of Staveley and his second wife, Margaret, baptised 14 March 1575. He sat in the House of Commons as MP for Derbyshire in 1601 and in 1621-22. He built Staveley Hall in 1604. He married twice, first Joyce Osborne (née Fleetwood), widow of Hewett Osborne, with whom he had three children (a son and two daughters) and secondly Isabel Neville who died without issue. His marriage to Joyce made him Alice Thornton's maternal step-grandfather. He died on 9 April 1634 and was buried at Staveley.]

data.title: Robert Garbutt (n. d.)
data.bio: [Robert Garbutt was a man active in the Ryedale area in 1668. This might be the Robert Garbutt baptised at Bilsdale Kirkham in 1617, or the one baptised at Coxwold in 1619. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Geoffrey Gates (died 1655)
data.bio: [Geoffrey Gates was the second husband of Elizabeth Gates, whom he married on 26 June 1638 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave, becoming the stepfather of William Thornton. In 1651 he refused to sign documents allowing his wife to dispose of her landed property, which meant William Thornton’s part of the marriage settlement with the Wandesfords was not legally binding. Gates died just eight days after his wife on 18 May 1655, and was buried at St Mary Lowgate, Hull on the 20th. On his death he was described as a colonel, suggesting military involvement.]

data.title: Sir John Gibson (1606-1665)
data.bio: [Sir John Gibson of Welborne (1606-65) was the son of Sir John and Anne Gibson, born 20 January 1606. He married Penelope Woodall on 18 June 1629, and they had four sons. He died on 13 June 1665.]

data.title: John Gibson (1630-1711)
data.bio: [This is probably John Gibson (1630-1711) of Welborne, son of Sir John and Penelope Gibson, born 4 August 1630. He married Joan Pennyman on 30 September 1650, and they had 10 children, six sons and four daughters. He died on 20 November 1711.]

data.title: Thomas Gill (born c.1632)
data.bio: [Thomas Gill of Barton was the second son of Thomas Gill and Elizabeth, daughter of Richard Wandesford of Pickhill, born c. 1632. He was a distant relation of Alice Thornton. The Pickhill Wandesfords became established in the later 16th century with Michael Wandesford, brother of Alice Thornton's great-great-great grandfather, Christopher Wandesford (d. 1540). An attorney, he married Elizabeth Smithson and they had 10 children, five sons and five daughters.]

data.title: Francelia (Celia) Parker (c.1659-c.1699)
data.bio: [Francelia Parker was the daughter of Christopher and Anne Danby; Alice Thornton's great-niece. Although born in Leeds c.1659 and brought up in Yorkshire, she moved to colonial Virginia, where her parents had met, and married Joseph Goodrich in or around 1685. They had two sons before his death in 1694. She married Thomas Parker later that year. Her will was witnessed on 25 March 1699 in James City County, Virginia.]

data.title: Susan Gosling (n. d.)
data.bio: [Susan Gosling was a servant in Alice Thornton's or her mother's household at Hipswell Hall in the 1650s. We have not traced her any further.]

data.title: Francis Graham (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Francis Graham was an acquaintance of Alice Thornton and Peter Samways in the late 1660s. He was possibly the Francis born c. 1614, brother of Ranald Graham of Nunnington.]

data.title: Ranald Graham (c.1605-1685)
data.bio: [Ranald Graham of London and Nunnington was the third son of Fergus and Sibill Graham of Plomp, born c. 1605. Apprenticed to a London merchant in 1622, he became a draper in Watling Street. By 1640 he was very wealthy and around this time he married Susannah Washington. The Grahams acquired Nunnington Hall in 1655 and Ranald and his wife moved from London. He became MP for Leominster in 1661 and Justice of the Peace of the North Riding of Yorkshire in 1662. He died without issue and his will was proved on 2 December 1685.]

data.title: Susanna Graham (1618-1699)
data.bio: [Susanna Graham (1618-99) was the daughter of William and Anne Washington, baptised 15 November 1618 at St-Martin-in-the-Fields, London. She married Ranald Graham of Lewisham c.1640. The couple purchased Nunnington Hall in Ryedale in 1655 and Ranald became Justice of the Peace of the North Riding of Yorkshire in 1662. This brought Susanna into the social circle of Alice Thornton, who counted her as a friend. She was godmother to Thornton's youngest daughter and eighth child Joyce, born in 1665. She died on 26 February 1699 and was buried in the parish church at Lewisham.]

data.title: John Hall (n. d.)
data.bio: [John Hall made two deeds with William Mitchell in April 1664. No further information on this man.]

data.title: Joseph Hall (1574-1656)
data.bio: [Joseph Hall (1574-1656) was the son of John and Winifred Hall, born on 1 July 1574 at Bristow Park, Ashby-de-la-Zouch. He was a religious writer, satirist, and became Bishop of Exeter (1627) and Norwich (1647). He married Elizabeth Winniff in 1603 with whom he had eight children, six sons and two daughters. He died on 8 September 1656.]

data.title: Mary Comber (1617-1672)
data.bio: [Mary Comber (1617-72) was the daughter of Brian and Alice Burton, baptised 14 September 1617 at Westerham, Kent. On 30 April 1638 she married Edward Hamden, a mercer, but he died less than a year later. They had one daughter. She then married James Comber of Allington in 1639. They had five children, two of whom survived to adulthood, James and Thomas. Thomas married Alice (Nally) Thornton and became Alice Thornton's son-in-law. She died on 13 May 1672 and was buried two days later at Stonegrave by her son.]

data.title: Thomas Hassell (c.1627-1694)
data.bio: [Thomas Hassell was the first son of Samuel and Mary Hassell of Hutton-on-Derwent, born c. 1627. He married Elizabeth Wood on 11 November 1647. He entered Gray's Inn in February 1648, becoming an Utter Barrister. He had seven children, three sons and four daughters. He was buried at St Michael's, Malton on 27 October 1694.]

data.title: Jane Heald (n. d.)
data.bio: [Jane Heald was a servant or acquaintance of Thornton who was in the Ryedale area in the early 1630s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Mary Heard (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mary Breakes was a servant in the Thornton household in the late 1660s. She married William Heard some time after she left the Thorntons' service. She was implicated in the rumours that were spread about Alice Thornton and Thomas Comber in 1668. We have not been able to trace her further but Thornton suggests she had died by the time Book 2 was finished, perhaps in the 1680s.]

data.title: William Heard (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Heard was the husband of Mary Breakes, a former servant of Alice Thornton. They married some time after Breakes left Thornton's service in 1668.]

data.title: John Hicke (n. d.)
data.bio: [John Hicke was an old friend of William Thornton's who lent Alice Thornton £150 after William's death. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Mrs Hickeringgill (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Hickeringgill was a woman, perhaps a midwife, in the Richmond area in 1660. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Elizabeth Hicks (n. d.)
data.bio: [Elizabeth Hicks was a tenant of Alice and William Thornton's at Newton Park in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Sir William Hildyard (1577-1632)
data.bio: [Sir William Hildyard of Bishop Wilton (1577-1632) was the eldest son of William and Anne Hildyard, baptised on 11 July 1577. He married Isabel Hansby, and they had six children; of which three daughters survived to adulthood. He died on 6 October 1632.]

data.title: [Unknown] Holland (n. d.)
data.bio: [An unnamed daughter of William Holland. We have not been able to identify her more precisely.]

data.title: William Holland (c.1620-1677)
data.bio: [William Holland was the son of George Holland, merchant of Doncaster, born c. 1620. He was educated at Sheffield Grammar School and St John’s, Cambridge, gaining his BA in 1642. He was ordained Deacon and then Priest in 1646. He became vicar of Westerham, Kent in 1657. During his time as vicar of Westerham he taught a young Thomas Comber. Holland was vicar of both Great Wakering, Essex and All Hallows Staining, London between 1663 and 1677. He died in October 1677.]

data.title: Thomas Hoyle (1587-1650)
data.bio: [Thomas Hoyle (1587-1650) was the son of Thomas Hoyle of Slaithwaite and his wife Elizabeth, baptised 29 January 1587. As a boy he was apprenticed to a merchant, Mr Topham of Micklegate, York. He married Elizabeth Maskewe in 1611 and they went on to have 13 children, all of whom except for one, Elizabeth (d. 1648) died before adulthood He married his second wife, Susanna, c.1641 and they had two sons – only John surviving to adulthood. Hoyle took up the Freedom of the city of York in 1612 and was warden of St Martin's, Micklegate in 1613. Rising up the civic ranks over the next 20 years, he became Alderman in 1626 and Mayor of York in 1632. A devout Presbyterian, he called for Charles I to be brought to justice but took no part in the king's trial. He hanged himself on 30 January 1650, exactly a year after the regicide, in his lodgings at Broad Sanctuary, Westminster.]

data.title: Mr Hubert (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Hubert was a man in the Dublin area in the 1630s who had been helped by Christopher Wandesford in a legal case. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Ellen Syddall (n. d.)
data.bio: [Ellen Syddall married twice, first Christopher Hunton, steward to Alice Thornton's father, Christopher Wandesford, at Kirklington in the 1620s and 1630s; and second to Michael Syddall, minister of Kirklington from 1644-49 and St Anne's Catterick from 1645-58.]

data.title: Anne Hutton (n. d.)
data.bio: [Anne Hutton may be the daughter of Thomas Wentworth's sister, Margaret, and her husband, Richard Hutton. Thornton describes her as a 'cousin', a kinship that could be claimed via great-great-grandfather George Bowes, to whom both the Wandesfords and Huttons were related. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Robert Innes (n. d.)
data.bio: [Captain Robert Innes, a Scottish soldier, served as quartermaster in the Earl of Leven’s Horse Regiment, commanded by Leven’s son, Alexander Leslie Lord Balgonie, in 1644. The major of this regiment was Sir Robert Adair of Kinhilt. He fought at the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644, after which his regiment was stationed in Catterick. According to Thornton, Innes plotted to abduct her after she refused his hand in marriage. Innes was still serving under Leven in 1646.]

data.search: Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin, County Dublin _place_Chri_086
data.title: Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin, County Dublin

data.search: St Patrick's Church, Dublin, County Dublin _place_StPa_092
data.title: St Patrick's Church, Dublin, County Dublin
Mr Jackson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Jackson is unidentified beyond Thornton’s account that she paid him to go to London to solicit on behalf of Thomas Comber for the living of Stonegrave in the mid-1660s.]

data.title: Ralph Janson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Ralph Janson of Thorpe was a friend or servant of Alice Thornton's in the early 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further, although a Ralph Janson of Newton-le-Willows, Richmondshire, petitioned for a soldier's pension in 1670, so he may have fought in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms.]

data.title: Thomas Jenney (n. d.)
data.bio: [Thomas Jenney was implicated in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew, Thomas Danby, in London, July 1667 but was pardoned and released from jail in October 1667.]

data.title: John Kearton (died 1664)
data.bio: [John Kearton, birth date unknown, received his BA from Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge. He was ordained deacon at York in 1628, and priest in 1629. He became rector of St Mary’s Richmond in 1657. Alice Thornton's mother wanted him to preach at her funeral service in 1659. In April 1660 he baptised, and then shortly afterwards buried, Thornton's sixth child, William, at St Agatha, Easby. Kearton was buried on 18 August 1664 at St Mary’s, Richmond.]

data.title: Frank Kelly (c.1634-1643)
data.bio: [Frank Kelly was an orphan boy taken into the household of Christopher Wandesford in Dublin, after Wandesford had encountered him while playing bowls on the green. He stayed with the family and moved with them to Chester in 1641. He was about nine when he died of smallpox at Chester in 1643.]

data.title: [Unknown] Kendall (n. d.)
data.bio: [Kendall was a woodworker in the Ryedale area active in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Mr Kerney (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Kerney was the Dublin landlord of one of the clerks of the Irish administration in the 1630s, who was still living in Dublin in the 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: John Lambert (1619-1684)
data.bio: [John Lambert (1619-84) was born on 7 September 1619 to Josias Lambert and his second or third wife, Anne. He was a Parliamentarian general during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms. He married Frances Lister on 10 September 1639, and they had 10 children, three of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 1 March 1684.]

data.title: Don de Lan (n. d.)
data.bio: [Don de Lan was a French page in the service of Robert Meredith, Chancellor of the Irish Exchequer, in the 1630s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Mr Lane (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Lane was a friend or acquaintance of Alice Thornton in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Anne Langdale (born 1611)
data.bio: [Anne Langdale was the third daughter of Robert and Dorothy Thornton of East Newton, baptised 3 December 1611 at Stonegrave. She was William Thornton's half-sister. She married Philip Langdale of Lanthorpe and they had one son.]

data.title: Philip Langdale (born c.1604)
data.bio: [Philip Langdale was the son of William and Elizabeth Langdale of Langthorpe, born c. 1604. He married Anne Thornton, William Thornton's older half-sister; Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. They had one son.]

data.title: Roger Lascelles (c.1557-1630)
data.bio: Roger Lascelles, born c.1557, was rector of St Michael’s, Kirklington from May 1590 until his death in July 1630. He baptised Alice Thornton in 1626. He died on 21 July 1630.

data.title: Ed(ward) (or Edmund) Lassells (n. d.)
data.bio: [Edward (or Edmund) Lassells was a coffin-bearer at the funeral of William Thornton in September 1668. Alice Thornton describes him as a cousin; her paternal great-aunt, Eleanor Wandesford, had married George Lassells and this man may have been a descendant of theirs. Perhaps he is the Edward Lassells who was buried on 22 August 1675 at St Michael-le-Belfrey, York.]

data.title: William Laud (1573-1645)
data.bio: [William Laud (1573-1645), Archbishop of Canterbury, was born on born on 7 October 1573 in Reading to William and Lucy Laud. He was educated at Reading school and then Oxford University and elected Archbishop of Canterbury in 1633. A royalist, he was executed on 10 January 1645.]

data.title: Richard Legard (1607-c.1680)
data.bio: [Richard Legard was the second son of John and Elizabeth Legard, baptised at Ganton on 15 March 1607. He was related to Alice Thornton via Alice's great-great-grandfather, George Bowes, who married Dorothy Mallory, the aunt of Legard's father. A barrister at the Middle Temple, he was admitted to Gray's Inn on 14 March 1625. He married Elizabeth, the daughter or widow of John Pierson of Mowthorpe on 14 August 1666 at Nunburnholme but had no children. He was a Royalist captain during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms and was godfather to Alice Thornton's eighth child and youngest daughter, Joyce, in September 1665. He died around 1680 (when his will was witnessed).]

data.title: David Leslie (1601-1682)
data.bio: [David Leslie, 1st Lord Newark (1601-82), the son of Patrick and Jean Leslie, was an army officer in the employ of Alexander Leslie, 1st Earl Leven. A key figure in the parliamentarian success at the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644 as Major-General of the Horse for his regiment, he was stationed in Yorkshire. He married Jane Yorke and they had nine children; three sons and six daughters. He was elevated to the title of 1st Lord Newark by Charles II. He died in February 1682.]

data.title: Lady Katherine Leveson (1598-1674)
data.bio: This is likely Lady Katherine Leveson (1598-1674), the daughter of the illegitimate son of the Elizabethan courtier Robert Dudley - also called Robert - and his first wife, Alice. Her mother lived at Dudley House, St Giles-in-the-Field. She married Sir Richard Leveson in 1609 at Kenilworth. She died February 1674 at Trentham, Kent, without issue, and in her will she endowed alms-houses and an education fund which survives to this day at Temple Balsall.

data.title: Daphne Lightfoot (died 1689)
data.bio: [Daphne Lightfoot entered the service of the Wandesford family as an unmarried woman with the family name Cassell, possibly beginning in the household of Alice Wandesford, Thornton's mother. She with Katherine Danby, Thornton's sister, when she died after childbirth in 1645 at Thorpe Perrow. Before 1654, she married another servant of Lady Wandesford’s, George Lightfoot. The couple had at least one child, a daughter named Mary. Daphne prayed with Lady Wandesford at her bedside in 1659, and she and her husband were witnesses to her will, in which they were left 20 shillings each. Daphne is described as wet-nursing Thornton’s daughter, Elizabeth (Betty), in 1655 while the family were living at Hipswell Hall. She provided a great deal of support to Thornton in the wake of her husband's death in September 1668. She was present with her daughter, Mary, at the private wedding of Thomas and Alice Comber on 17 November 1668. Daphne and her husband might still have been working at East Newton Hall in 1682 when George is mentioned in a letter from Thomas Comber to Thornton. She was buried on 20 September 1689 at St Agatha’s, Gilling West.]

data.title: George Lightfoot (n. d.)
data.bio: [George Lightfoot was a servant in the household of Alice Wandesford in the 1650s. He married another of the household servants, Daphne Cassell, before 1654, and they had at least one child, a daughter. A literate man, he and Daphne were witnesses to Alice Wandesford's will in 1659. It seems likely that after her death, the Lightfoots entered the Thorntons’ service as there are indications of them working at East Newton after 1668, and then going into the service of the Combers. George and his wife might still have been working at East Newton Hall in 1682 when he is mentioned in a letter from Thomas Comber to his mother-in-law. We do not know when he died.]

data.title: Mary Lightfoot (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mary Lightfoot was the daughter of George and Daphne Lightfoot. We have not been able to identify her any further.]

data.title: [Unknown] Lister (n. d.)
data.bio: [Cousin Lister was a relation of Alice Thornton who lived in the Ripon area. We have not been able to trace them further.]

data.title: Edward Loftus (c.1598-1680)
data.bio: [Edward Loftus, 2nd Viscount Elye was the second son of Adam and Sarah Loftus, born c.1598. His father was Lord Chancellor of Ireland. He married Jane Lindley and through her inherited Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, where Alice Thornton's sister, Katherine Danby, gave birth to her penultimate child in August 1644. The Loftus, Wentworth and Wandesford families were close associates in Ireland. Edward and Jane had two children, a son and a daughter. He died on 11 April 1680.]

data.title: Robert Loftus (1614-1672)
data.bio: [Robert Loftus of Waithwith was possibly born in 1614 at St Mary’s, Richmond to William Loftus. A servant of Alice Wandesford, he was present at the wedding of Alice and William Thornton in 1651 and is mentioned in Alice Wandesford’s will of 1659 (but could not sign his name), in which he was named as her servant. He had four daughters and a son. He may have been the local man to whom the Thorpe Edge lead mine in Swaledale was leased in 1656 along with Robert Barker and some Derbyshire investors. His will, dated 29 August 1672, shows that he owed money to Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother. He was buried at St Michael and All Angels, Hudswell, North Yorkshire.]

data.title: William Lowcock (died 1678)
data.bio: [William Lowcock was rector of All Saints, Nunnington from 1658 until his death in 1678. He married Helen Bentley of Pannal on 10 October 1661 at Nunnington and they had two daughters and two sons. He baptised Alice Thornton's son, Robert, in 1662 at the family home, East Newton Hall. He died on 31 July 1678.]

data.title: Sir John Lowther (1606-1675)
data.bio: [Sir John Lowther, 1st Baronet Lowther (1606-75) and Sheriff of Cumberland was born on 20 February 1606 to Sir John and Eleanor Lowther. He graduated from the Inner Temple in 1621 and was called to the bar in 1630. He married Mary, daughter of Richard Fletcher of Hutton, Cumbria, before 1628; they had 11 children, five sons and six daughters. His second wife was Elizabeth Hare, by whom he had four children, three sons and a daughter. His eldest daughter with Mary, Eleanor, married Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother, after having been engaged to her elder brother George who then died in 1651. According to Thornton, he tried to get both George, and later Christopher, to destroy their father's will. He was twice elected MP for Westmorland, in 1628-29 (with his father) and again in 1660. He fought for the royalists during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms. He died on 30 November 1675 and is buried at St Michael’s church, Lowther alongside his father, also commemorated by a Latin inscription.]

data.title: Hugh Óg MacMahon (c.1606-1644)
data.bio: [Hugh Óg MacMahon was a younger son of Brian Hugh Óg MacMahon and his wife Mary, born in 1606 or 1607. He was an Irish conspirator in the failed 1641 plot to seize Dublin Castle during the Irish Rebellion and it was his drunken confession to his Protestant foster brother, Owen Connolly, which brought down the plot. He was imprisoned in the Tower of London, along with co-conspirator Conor Maguire. They escaped for five months in August 1644 but were captured. He was put on trial on 13 November 1644 and executed at Tyburn on 22 November.]

data.title: Connor Maguire (1616-1645)
data.bio: [Connor Maguire (1616-45), 2nd Baron Enniskillen, was the eldest son of Brian Roe and Rose Maguire. He attended Oxford University but did not graduate. On his father's death in 1632, he became 2nd Baron Enniskillen. He married Mary Fleming, and they had one son. As a member of the House of Lords in Ireland, he was one of the conspirators in the failed plot to seize Dublin Castle during the Irish rebellion of 1641 and was imprisoned in the Tower of London. He escaped for five weeks in 1644, but was recaptured, stood trial and executed at Tyburn on 20 February 1645.]

data.title: Dr Richard(?) Mahum (died 1659)
data.bio: [Dr Mahum, described by Thornton as her 'old doctor', may be the same Richard Mahum who witnessed her mother's will in 1659. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Captain Mainwaring (n. d.)
data.bio: [Captain Mainwaring could be William Mainwaring, son of Edmund Mainwaring, killed during the Siege of Chester in 1645; or Philip Mainwaring, son of Randle and Jane Mainwaring (d.1647), who is referred to as a 'captaine of the horse'. Both were involved in the defence of Chester.]

data.title: Dr Edmund Mainwaring (1579-c.1643)
data.bio: [Edmund Mainwaring was the second son of Randle and Margaret Mainwaring of Over Peover, Cheshire, born in 1579. He matriculated at Brasenose College, Oxford in 1594 and All Souls in 1600. He married a woman called Jane, and they had three children, a daughter and two sons, who were baptised at York. A civil lawyer, he held various positions before becoming Chancellor of Chester in 1634. He died c.1643.]

data.title: Jane Mainwaring (n. d.)
data.bio: [Jane Mainwaring was the wife of Edmund Mainwaring. Her birth name is unknown, but she is thought to have come from York. She and Edmund married before 1614 had three children, a daughter and two sons.]

data.title: Charles Man (c.1643-1710)
data.bio: [Charles Man was the second son of Charles Man, yeoman of Helmsley, Yorkshire, born c. 1643. He attended Helmsley and York schools, matriculating Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge on 1 June 1660, gaining his MA in 1667. He then became rector of Gilling, Yorkshire, and performed the marriage ceremony of Thomas and Alice Comber in 1668. He had a son, Charles, and was buried at Gilling on 28 March 1710.]

data.title: George Masterman (n. d.)
data.bio: [George Masterman was a man living in the Stonegrave area in 1663. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Frances Maude (died 1690)
data.bio: [Frances Maude was the daughter of Christopher Wandesford, 1st Baronet of Kirklington and his wife Eleanor; Alice Thornton's niece. She married Robert Maude of West Riddleston and Ripon, and they had a son and two daughters. She died on 5 January 1690.]

data.title: Lady Arabella McCarthy (1630-1697?)
data.bio: Lady Arabella McCarthy was born in October 1630 in London, the daughter of Thomas Wentworth and his second wife, Arabella. She was a childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin. She married Justin MacCarthy, 1st Viscount Mountcashel, about 13 years her junior. She was still alive (but ill) on 14 April 1697, when mentioned in a letter by Alice Thornton to Abstrupus Danby, and died without issue.

data.title: Sir Robert Meredith (c.1597-1668)
data.bio: [Robert Meredith was the son of Richard and Sarah Meredith, born c.1597. His father was Bishop of Leighlin. He married Anne Usher and they had three sons. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer of Ireland from 1634 until his death. He held a Greenhills estate in Kildare. He died on 17 October 1668 and was buried in the family vault at St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin.]

data.title: Sander Metcalfe (n. d.)
data.bio: [Sander (Alexander?) Metcalfe lived in the Yorkshire Dales in 1644. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: William Metcalfe (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Metcalfe was a solicitor, in the employ of William Wandesford, Alice Thornton's uncle. Metcalfe acted as William Thornton's agent in Ireland in the 1650s, tasked with locating Christopher Wandesford's lost will.]

data.title: Anne Osborne (died 1666)
data.bio: [Anne Osborne was the daughter of Thomas Walmesley of Dunkenhalgh and his first wife, Eleanor. She married William Middleton and they had no children. On his death, she married (before 1630) Edward Osborne, Alice Thornton's maternal uncle, and became his second wife. They had a son, Thomas. She was buried on 20 August 1666 at Harthill.]

data.title: Anne (Nan) Milbank (n. d.)
data.bio: [Anne Milbank, also known as Nan, was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Margery Millbanke (n. d.)
